subject: probability
title: Random Walks
contentHtml:
A random walk is a stochastic process that moves in discrete steps along a line or in space.

Imagine flipping a coin to decide whether to move left or right at each step, with equal probability of either outcome. This simple concept has far-reaching implications in many fields, including finance and machine learning.
intuition: Random walks are a great way to model real-world phenomena where uncertainty is involved. They can help us understand and predict the behavior of complex systems.
realWorldApplications: Modeling user behavior in recommendation systems
commonMistakes: Assuming the walk always returns to its starting point
Ignoring the impact of boundary conditions

subject: probability
title: Random Walks
subtitle: Exploring chance and uncertainty
contentHtml:
A random walk is a mathematical process that models a sequence of independent and identically distributed (i.i.d.) random steps. Each step can be thought of as moving either up or down by one unit, with equal probability.

This simple yet powerful concept has far-reaching implications in fields like finance, biology, and computer science.
intuition: Think of a random walk as a game where you flip a coin to decide whether to move up or down. The more steps you take, the more likely you are to be close to your starting point.
visualDescription: A simple diagram showing a sequence of random steps could help illustrate this concept
commonMistakes: Assuming the walk will always return to the origin

subject: probability
title: Random Walks
contentHtml:
A random walk is a stochastic process that moves in discrete steps along a line or in higher-dimensional space.

At each step, the walker has an equal chance of moving left or right (or up or down in higher dimensions). This simple process has many surprising properties and applications.
intuition: The key insight is that the walker's position at any given step is a sum of independent random variables. This allows us to use tools from probability theory, like the Central Limit Theorem.
realWorldApplications: Random walk models for stock prices
commonMistakes: Failing to recognize that each step is an independent event
